Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: AERODYNAMIC FLOW DEFLECTOR FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE WIND TURBINES TO INCREASE THE ANNUAL ENERGY PRODUCTION BY 10% AND REDUCE THE LEVELIZED COST OF ENERGY BY 8%
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is in enabling more efficient Annual Wind Energy Production (AEP) while reducing the cost of energy (COE). This will make wind energy more attractive economically, improve the energy security of the U.S, create jobs, and indirectly help reduce greenhouse gas emissions. A 2% AEP increase is generally considered attractive. Two turbines (5kW and 50kW) tested during Phase I have shown an increase in AEP between 2% to 8% while reducing the COE by 1% to 6%. About 150,000 turbines worldwide can be potentially be retrofitted with this technology.

This project will address challenges related to aerodynamic efficiency of wind turbines and the cost of wind energy. It is based on a deeper understanding of wind turbine aerodynamics from a more 3-dimensional point of view; most wind turbine designs are based on 2- dimensional theories. The key technical challenge in bringing this technology to market is to demonstrate the increase in AEP of utility scale turbines retrofitted with our deflector technology in realistic field conditions while reducing the COE. This will be addressed by performing testing at a few customer wind farms and NREL testing centers. The R&D plan consists of designing, manufacturing, and installing deflectors on a few utility size turbines (30-100 meters diameter rotors). The tests will include power performance comparison between baseline and retrofitted turbines according to international standards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lowering the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) is a priority for all wind energy segments. Due to the high capital requirements for these structures, any reduction in LCOE through turbine efficiencies will pay significant dividends in the Wind Farm Owners? return-on-investment (ROI). Thereby increasing the overall competitiveness of the wind energy sector. Our deflectors technology innovation has the potential to address both the efficiency demands of wind farm owners (reducing time until ROIs) as well as to provide a disruptive design innovation to wind turbine manufacturers, providing them a sustainable competitive edge (reduced LCOE). An important emphasis to make regarding this technology is that it can be retrofitted to existing turbines as well as incorporated into the design of newly manufactured blades without increasing their diameters.

During the NSF SBIR Phase II, the aerodynamic deflectors were tested two commercial turbines (GE1.5MW SLE and Endurance X35i 225kW) at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NWTC wind farm test facility) and one of the NREL Regional Testing Centers (Windward Engineering). All data was collected and processed following IEC 61400-12-1 power performance standards. These third-party measurements showed that the Annual Energy Production (AEP) increased substantially (2-4%) when retrofitting the deflectors into both commercial turbines. In addition, the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) reduced substantially (1-2%). Moreover, the technology has shown to scale up seamlessly. From wind tunnel measurements to full size field tests, we have observed significant AEP increments when using our technology. Currently, we are piloting the technology at a few wind farms in the US and the EU.

Our product leads to more efficient wind energy production while reducing the cost of energy. This will make wind energy more economically attractive, improve the energy security of the U.S, create hundreds/thousands of jobs, and help to reduce coal and natural gas emissions as an alternative renewable energy source.

By using our technology over the 66,000+ operating utility wind turbines in the U.S., a 3% AEP increase would generate the following benefits:

  • Power additional 38,000 US homes a year without adding more wind farms or distribution capabilities
  • Reduced carbon pollution by 200,000 metric tons a year
  • Create hundreds/thousands of new jobs in manufacturing and installation
  • Make wind energy more competitive with the potential of further growth of the industry
  • Improve national energy security

This technology also enhances wind turbine aerodynamics understanding from a 3-dimensional point of view. Most wind turbine designs are based on 2D theories that assume 3D losses. Theories are then modified to include 3D empirical corrections. Our technology take advantage of the 3-dimensional behavior of the velocity to increase the output power and therefore reduce losses.
